docs.abstract: Mexico City's air is among most polluted in world; public buses, open dumps, unsupervised industries and aging cars cough out contaminants, and now there is new indignity: clouds of particles bearing fecal matter; Health Ministry survey shows fully half of city's 18 million residents are sick with some respiratory ailment; environmentalists say Mexican officials are to blame, but important part of inertia comes from citizens, who are sunk in cycle of self-fulfilling powerlessness; they do not believe they can bring about change in problem as stubborn and pervasive as smog, so they do not try; there has never been groundswell of popular outrage to push decision-makers to make ambitious changes needed to achieve drastic reductions in pollution; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS winter the residents of Mexico City, who are long accustomed to breathing toxic concentrations of ozone, are also breathing poisonous amounts of something else: tiny airborne particles of bus exhaust, industrial smoke, garbage and what the authorities refer to, with scientific detachment, as fecal matter. Since December the city government has twice declared pollution emergencies in which, for the first time, the chief cause was not ozone but dismal clouds of particles. Schoolchildren were required to stay indoors and vehicles with dirty engines were barred from the streets. Health Ministry surveys showed that within a week after the highest particle levels were registered, fully half of the metropolis's 18 million residents became sick with some respiratory ailment.

headline.main: Victor G. Bloede, 79, Ex-Chief Of Benton & Bowles, Is Dead

docs.abstract: Victor G Bloede, former chairman and chief executive of Benton & Bowles Advertising, dies at age 79; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Victor G. Bloede, a former advertising executive who helped introduce the slogan ''Good to the last drop'' for Maxwell House coffee as well as other enduring advertising campaigns for consumer products, died on Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla., from complications after surgery. He was 79. In his career, Mr. Bloede rose to chairman and chief executive of Benton & Bowles Advertising, where he was hired as a copywriter in 1950.
